node.title: Queensland moves to allow use of police body cam footage in prosecution of domestic violence perpetrators
node.alt: A camera on a Queensland police officer's shoulder
node.description: The use of police footage of statements taken from victims of domestic and family violence could be used as evidence in court proceedings, after a new bill was introduced in state parliament today.
node.content:
["Police footage of statements taken from victims in the aftermath of domestic and family violence will be used as evidence in\u00a0prosecuting\u00a0their attacker, under a raft of new government reforms introduced in state parliament today.", "The reforms are aimed at\u00a0reducing\u00a0the trauma of victims having to retell their stories and the video-recorded statements will only be allowed to be taken with a complainant's \"informed consent\".", "The camera footage would be taken by trained police officers, most likely from body-worn cameras.", "The video statements would\u00a0be used as the victim's \"evidence in chief\"\u00a0for domestic violence-related offences and breaches of domestic violence orders in\u00a012-month trials\u00a0at the Southport and Ipswich magistrates courts.", "Attorney-General and\u00a0Minister for the Prevention of Domestic and Family Violence, Shannon Fentiman, said the pilot program in the proposed bill\u00a0would better support domestic and family violence victims during court hearings.", "\"These reforms include a range of safeguards designed to limit the trauma and protect the privacy of victims who provide their evidence under the pilot,\" she said in a statement to ABC News.", "\"The Palaszczuk Government is always looking at ways we can better support victims to come forward and hold perpetrators to account.", "\"We know that having to recount a domestic violence incident during a court hearing can be extremely traumatic for the victim.", "The police video footage would\u00a0be used as an official statement as evidence-in-chief and not for cross-examination.", "
Recommendation of landmark 2015 domestic violence report\u00a0
", "Legislation for the use of evidence\u00a0would\u00a0not replace the admissibility of other police-recorded evidence that would ordinarily be used before the court, a spokesperson for Ms Fentiman said.", "They said the finer details of the pilot, including whether it would\u00a0apply to committal proceedings for more serious offences in those courts, will need to be finalised through consultation, particularly with the Chief Magistrate once the legislation has passed, which will be next year after it has been debated in the house.", "Ms Fentiman said while similar measures have been used in Queensland courts for several years for vulnerable witnesses, including children, \"it is important that evidence can be obtained about the impacts and experiences that are unique to domestic and family violence cases\".", "The initiative was born out of the 2015 Not Now, Not Ever\u00a0report's recommendations that the Attorney-General, in consultation with the Chief Magistrate and Chief Judge, implement alternative evidence procedures for victims of domestic and family violence, providing evidence in related criminal matters.", "The recommendation also included consideration be given to allowing the admissibility of any video recordings made at the time of initial police intervention.", "Video-recorded evidence of domestic and family violence victims\u00a0used in other states, including NSW and Tasmania, have enabled victims to tell their story while it is fresh in their mind and not in the presence of perpetrators."]
